sn9.11:1.1: This short discourse offers a concise version of meditation advice given in more detail at MN 19.
sn9.11:1.2: Even ascetics in the forest can be consumed by bad thoughts.
sn9.11:1.4: Trapped in a spiral of unwholesome thoughts, a meditator may feel guilty or worthless. But the deity has only compassion.
sn9.11:2.1: This term has already appeared at SN 4.4:2.1, and plays a key role in dependent origination (SN 12.4:2.3). Their thoughts are irrational because they lead to the opposite of their goal, freedom.
sn9.11:3.1: Unwholesome thoughts are replaced by wholesome ones (cf. MN 20:3.1). The meditator is not urged to stop thinking; quietness is a process.
sn9.11:3.5: Suffering spurs on the practice, but the path itself is characterized by joy.
